pli-tv-kd19:0.4_0: The request for the recitation of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.11_0: At the end of the last part of the night, Venerable Ānanda asked a third time,
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.12_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the last watch of the night and dawn stirs, bringing joy to the night.
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.14_0: And the Buddha replied, “Ānanda, the gathering is impure.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, in Migāramāta’s stilt house.
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.2_0: On one occasion on the observance day, he was seated surrounded by the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.3_0: Then, when the night was well advanced and the first part of the night was over, Venerable Ānanda got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, raise his joined palms, and said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.4_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the Saṅgha has been sitting long.
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.7_0: At the end of the middle part of the night, Venerable Ānanda asked a second time,
pli-tv-kd19:1.1.8_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the middle watch of the night, and the Saṅgha has been sitting long.
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.10_0: Mahāmoggallāna said the same thing a second
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.11_0: he asked that monk to leave.
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.12_0: You don’t belong to the community of monks.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.15_0: he asked that monk to leave.
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.16_0: You don’t belong to the community of monks.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.18_0: Mahāmoggallāna then grabbed him by the arms, took him outside the gateway, and fastened the bolts. And he went to the Buddha and said,
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.19_0: “Sir, I have taken that person outside;
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.22_0: “It’s amazing, Moggallāna, how that fool waited until he was grabbed by the arms.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.23_0: When the message had been delivered, the Buddha said to the monks,
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.4_0: He then read the minds of the the the entire Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.5_0: He saw that unethical person, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved, sitting in the middle of the Saṅgha.
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.6_0: He went up to him and said,
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.7_0: he asked that monk to leave.
pli-tv-kd19:1.2.8_0: You don’t belong to the community of monks.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.10_0: The ocean does not tolerate dead bodies,
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.11_0: This is the third thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.12_0: When the great rivers—the Ganges, the Yamunā, the Aciravatī, the Sarabhū, or the Mahī—reach the ocean, they lose their former names and become known simply as the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.13_0: When they reach the ocean, all the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—lose their names and clans and are simply considered ‘the ocean’.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.14_0: This is the fourth thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.15_0: Whatever rivers in the world flow into the ocean and whatever rain falls into it, the ocean is not diminished or filled up because of that.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.16_0: For all the world’s streams that reach it, and the rain that falls from the sky, the ocean never empties or fills up.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.17_0: This is the fifth thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.18_0: Furthermore, the ocean has just one taste, the taste of salt.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.1_0: “Monks, the antigods delight in the ocean when they see these eight amazing qualities in it:
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.20_0: This is the sixth thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.21_0: Furthermore, the ocean is full of many kinds of treasures, such as the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.21_1: This gem is the beryl gem that’s naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, red, and magenta.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.23_0: This is the seventh thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.24_0: Furthermore, many great beings live in the ocean, such as leviathans, leviathan-gulpers, leviathan-gulper-gulpers, demons, dragons, and fairies.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.24_1: In the world, the demons, dragons, and fairies.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.24_2: In the ocean there are life-forms a hundred leagues long, or even two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, or five hundred leagues long.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.25_0: In this ocean there are great beings.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.25_1: There are life-forms a hundred leagues long,
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.25_2: Right there are five hundred leagues long.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.26_0: This is the eighth thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.27_0: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things the demons love the ocean.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.3_0: The ocean slopes and inclines gradually. It does not drop off all at once.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.4_0: This is the ocean slopes and inclines gradually.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.5_0: This is the first thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.6_0: The ocean is steady. It does not go beyond the shoreline.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.7_0: When the ocean is steady and does not go beyond the shoreline,
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.8_0: This is the second thing the demons love about the ocean.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.9_0: Furthermore, the ocean does not have a corpse.
pli-tv-kd19:1.3.9_1: but quickly carries it to the shore and strands it on the beach.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.0_0: and eight amazing qualities on this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.10_0: This is the second thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.11_0: Just as the ocean does not tolerate dead bodies, but quickly carries them to the shore and discards them on dry land,
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.12_0: In the same way, the Saṅgha doesn’t accommodate a person who is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.12_1: When the Sangha has gathered , they quickly eject him. Even if he is seated in the midst of the Sangha, he is far from the Sangha and the Sangha is far from him.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.13_0: But in the middle of the Saṅgha,
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.14_0: This is the third thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.15_0: Just as when the great rivers—the Ganges, the Yamunā, the Aciravatī, the Sarabhū, or the Mahī—reach the ocean, they lose their former names and become known simply as the ocean,
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.16_0: In the same way, there are four castes—aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers—
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.16_1: They formerly gone forth from the lay life to homelessness—whether in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, and they lose their former name.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.17_0: There are some aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers who go forth from the lay life to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One—they lose their former names and class and become known simply as Sakyans ascetics.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.18_0: This is the fourth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.19_0: For all the world’s streams that reach it, and the rain that falls from the sky, the ocean never empties or fills up.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.1_0: “Just so, the monks delight in this spiritual path when they see these eight amazing qualities in it:
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.20_0: so too, even if many monks are extinguished without remainder, there is no decrease or filling up of the element of extinguishment.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.21_0: While many monks are extinguished without remainder, there is no decrease or filling up of the element of extinguishment.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.22_0: This is the fifth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.23_0: Just as the ocean has only one taste, the taste of salt,
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.24_0: so too, this spiritual path has only one taste, the taste of freedom.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.25_0: This is a one taste of freedom.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.26_0: This is the sixth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.27_0: Just as the ocean contains many precious things—pearls, gems, beryls, mother-of-pearls, quartz, corals, silver, gold, rubies, and cat’s eyes—
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.28_0: so too, this spiritual path has been full of many kinds of treasures, such as the sweetness.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.28_1: There are these four kinds of mindfulness meditation: the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.29_1: The noble eightfold path, that is:
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.30_0: This is the seventh thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.31_0: Just as there are great beings in the ocean—sea-monsters, antigods, dragons, and divinities; creatures with bodies one thousand kilometers long, two thousand, three thousand, four thousand, and five thousand kilometers long—
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.32_0: so too, there are great beings on this spiritual path—
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.32_1: The stream-enterer and the one practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.32_2: The once-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of once-return.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.32_3: non-returners, those practicing to realize the fruit of non-return.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.32_4: The perfected one and the one practicing for perfection.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.33_1: The perfected one, the one practicing for perfection.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.34_0: This is the eighth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.35_0: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things, the mendicants love this teaching and training.”
pli-tv-kd19:1.4.36_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:

pli-tv-kd19:2.1.10_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.11_0: The person so-and-so has an unconfessed offense. I cancel his hearing of the Monastic Code. The Monastic Code should not be recited in his presence.’ Then the Monastic Code is canceled for him.”
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.1_0: When the message had been delivered, the Buddha said to the monks,
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.2_0: “From now on I won’t do the observance-day procedure or recite the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.3_0: You will be doing it instead.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.4_0: It’s impossible for the Buddha to do the observance-day procedure and recite the Monastic Code in an impure gathering.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.5_0: And, monks, you should not listen to the Monastic Code if you have an unconfessed offense.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.7_0: If anyone who has an unconfessed offense listens to the Monastic Code, I allow you to cancel his hearing of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.8_0: And it should be done like this.
pli-tv-kd19:2.1.9_0: On the observance day, whether the fourteenth or the fifteenth, in the midst of the Sangha and in the presence of that person, you should announce:
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.11_0: thinking to act before the good monks canceled their Monastic Code,
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.12_0: the monks from the group of six canceled, without reason, the Monastic Code of the pure monks to preempt them.
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.13_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.14_0: “How can the monks from the group of six cancel the Monastic Code of pure monks without reason?”
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.15_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.16_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six did this?”
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.19_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.1_0: When the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.20_0: “You should not, without reason, cancel the Monastic Code of pure monks who don’t have any offenses.
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.21_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.2_0: thinking that nobody knew about them, the monks from the group of six listened to the Monastic Code while having unconfessed offenses.
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.3_0: The senior monks who could read the minds of others
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.5_0: thinking that nobody knew about them, the monks from the group of six listened to the Monastic Code while having unconfessed offenses.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.1.7_0: “So it seems the senior monks who could read the minds of others

pli-tv-kd19:3.2.0_0: are legitimate, a procedure of further penalty against the Monastic Code.

pli-tv-kd19:3.3.10_0: What are the two kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code that are legitimate?
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.11_0: One cancels the Monastic Code, having grounds, for failure in morality or for failure in conduct.

pli-tv-kd19:3.3.14_0: One cancels the Monastic Code, without grounds, for failure in morality, for failure in conduct, or for failure in view.

pli-tv-kd19:3.3.7_0: “What are the two kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code that are illegitimate?
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.80_0: “What are the ten kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code that are illegitimate?
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.81_0: There is no-one seated in that gathering who has committed an offense entailing expulsion; there is no unfinished discussion on anyone committing an offense entailing expulsion;
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.82_0: no-one seated in that gathering has renounced the training; there is no unfinished discussion on anyone renouncing the training;
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.83_0: he goes to the legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly; he doesn’t reopen a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly; there is no unfinished discussion on the reopening of a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly;
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.84_0: no-one has seen, heard, or suspects any failure in morality; no-one has seen, heard, or suspects any failure in conduct; no-one has seen, heard, or suspects any failure in view.
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.85_0: These are the ten kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.86_0: What are the ten kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code that are legitimate?
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.87_0: There is someone seated in that gathering who has committed an offense entailing expulsion; there is an unfinished discussion on someone committing an offense entailing expulsion;
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.88_0: someone seated in that gathering has renounced the training; there is an unfinished discussion on someone renouncing the training;
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.89_0: he doesn’t go to a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly; he reopens a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly; there is an unfinished discussion on the reopening of a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly;
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.8_0: One cancels the Monastic Code, without grounds, for failure in morality or for failure in conduct.
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.90_0: someone has seen, heard, or suspects failure in morality; someone has seen, heard, or suspects failure in conduct; someone has seen, heard, or suspects failure in view.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.91_0: These are the ten kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd19:3.3.9_0: These are the two kinds of canceling of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-kd19:3.4.0_0: are legitimate canceling of the Monastic Code.

pli-tv-kd19:3.4.20_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
pli-tv-kd19:3.4.21_0: There is an unfinished discussion on so-and-so who has not been decided.

pli-tv-kd19:3.6.3_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk not going to a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly, but another monk informs him,

pli-tv-kd19:3.7.3_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk reopening a legitimate legal procedure of a complete assembly, but another monk informs him,

pli-tv-kd19:3.8.11_0: the cancellation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.1_0: “And how is someone seen, heard, or suspected?
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.2_0: A monk sees in a monk the characteristics and signs of someone who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in morality.
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.3_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in morality, but another monk informs him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.4_0: ‘Monk so-and-so has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in morality.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.5_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in morality, nor does another monk inform him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.6_0: but the monk himself informs him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.7_0: ‘I have been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in morality.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.8_0: If a monk sees that the fourteenth day of the lunar half-month, the observance-day procedure, or the fourteenth day of the fifteenth day sabbath, or in that person in the presence of that person:
pli-tv-kd19:3.8.9_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.10_0: So-and-so has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in conduct. I cancel his hearing of the Monastic Code. The Monastic Code should not be recited in his presence.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.11_0: the cancellation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.12_0: “And how is failure in view seen, heard, or suspected?
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.13_0: A monk sees in a monk the characteristics and signs of someone who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in view.
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.14_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in view, but another monk informs him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.15_0: ‘Monk so-and-so has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in view.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.16_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in view, nor does another monk inform him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.17_0: but the monk himself informs him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.18_0: ‘I have been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in view.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.19_0: If a monk sees that the fourteenth day of the lunar half-month, the observance-day procedure, or the fourteenth day of the fifteenth day sabbath, or in that person in the presence of that person:
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.1_0: “And how is failure in conduct seen, heard, or suspected?
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.20_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.21_0: So-and-so has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in view. I cancel his hearing of the Monastic Code. The Monastic Code should not be recited in his presence.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.22_0: the cancellation of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.23_0: These are the ten legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.”
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.24_0: The first section for recitation is finished.
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.2_0: A monk sees in a monk the characteristics and signs of someone who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in conduct.
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.3_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in conduct, but another monk informs him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.4_0: ‘Monk so-and-so has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in conduct.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.5_0: Or a monk doesn’t see a monk who has been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in conduct, nor does another monk inform him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.6_0: but the monk himself informs him,
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.7_0: ‘I have been seen, heard, or suspected of failure in conduct.’
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.8_0: If a monk sees that the fourteenth day of the lunar half-month, the observance-day procedure, or the fourteenth day of the fifteenth day sabbath, or in that person in the presence of that person:
pli-tv-kd19:3.9.9_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.10_0: it’s the right time, he should reflect further
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.11_0: whether or not it’s a real issue.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.13_0: it’s not, he shouldn’t raise it.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.14_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.15_0: it’s real, he should reflect further
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.16_0: whether or not raising the issue will be beneficial.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.18_0: it won’t, he shouldn’t raise it.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.19_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.1_0: Soon afterwards Venerable Upāli approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.20_0: it will be beneficial, he should reflect further
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.21_0: whether or not the monks who are on the side of the Teaching and the Monastic Law will take his side.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.23_0: that they won’t, he shouldn’t raise it.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.24_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.25_0: they will take his side, he should reflect further
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.26_0: whether or not raising the issue will lead to arguments and disputes, to fracture and schism in the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.28_0: it will, he shouldn’t raise it.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.29_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.2_0: and told him what had happened,
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.30_0: it won’t, he may raise the issue.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.31_0: In this way, when five factors are fulfilled, he won’t regret raising it.”
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.3_0: “Venerable Sir, if a monk wishes to raise an issue, what factors should be fulfilled?”
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.4_0: “If a monk who wishes to raise an issue, five factors should be fulfilled:
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.6_0: whether or not it’s a real issue.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.8_0: it’s the wrong time, he shouldn’t raise it.
pli-tv-kd19:4.1.9_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.0_0: The qualities to be reflected upon by one who accuses another.
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.10_0: there will be those who say,
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.11_0: ‘Please train your own verbal conduct first.’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.13_0: ‘Do I have a mind of good will toward my fellow monastics? Am I free from ill will toward them? Is this quality found in me or not?’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.14_0: If it’s not, there will be those who say,
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.15_0: ‘Please set up a mind of good will toward your fellow monastics first.’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.17_0: ‘Have I learned much and do I retain and accumulate what I’ve learned?
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.17_1: Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, that have a true goal and are well articulated, and that set out the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—have I learned many such teachings, retained them in mind, recited them verbally, mentally investigated them, and penetrated them well by view?
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.17_2: Is this quality found in me or not?’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a monk see in himself before accusing another?”
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.21_0: ‘Have I properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; have I well analyzed them, thoroughly mastered them, and well investigated them, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition?
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.21_1: Is this quality found in me or not?’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.22_0: If it’s not, then when he is asked, ‘Where was this said by the Buddha?’ he won’t be able to reply. And there will be those who say,
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.24_0: A monk should see these five qualities in himself before accusing another.”
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.2_0: “A monk should see five qualities in himself before accusing another.
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.3_0: Before accusing another, a monk should reflect,
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.4_0: ‘Is my bodily conduct pure and faultless?
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.4_1: Is this quality found in me or not?’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.5_0: If it’s not, there will be those who say,
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.6_0: ‘Please train your own bodily conduct first.’
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.8_0: ‘Is my verbal conduct pure and faultless?
pli-tv-kd19:5.1.8_1: Is this quality found in me or not?’
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.0_0: The qualities to be set up by one who accuses another
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.1_0: “Sir, how many qualities should a monk set up in himself before accusing another?”
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.2_0: “A monk should set up five qualities in himself before accusing another. He should think,
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.3_0: I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.4_0: I’ll speak the truth, not falsehood;
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.6_0: I’ll speak what’s beneficial, not what’s unbeneficial;
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.7_0: I’ll speak with a mind of good will, not with internal ill will.’”
pli-tv-kd19:5.2.8_0: A monk should set up these five qualities in himself before accusing another.”
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.0_0: Discussion of the one who accuses and the one who is accused.
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.10_0: So that other monks won’t think to accuse others falsely.”
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.1_0: “Sir, if a monk accuses another illegitimately, in how many ways should regret be aroused in him?”
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.2_0: “Non-regret should be aroused in him in five ways:
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.3_0: ‘Venerable, you’re accusing at the wrong time, not the right time; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.4_0: You’re accusing falsely, not truthfully; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.5_0: You’re accusing harshly, not gently; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.6_0: You’re accusing unbeneficially, not beneficially; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.7_0: You’re accusing with internal ill will, not with a mind of good will; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.’
pli-tv-kd19:5.3.8_0: These are the five ways regret should be aroused in a monk who accuses another illegitimately.
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.1_0: “And if a monk has been accused illegitimately, in how many ways should non-regret be aroused in him?”
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.2_0: “Non-regret should be aroused in him in five ways:
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.3_0: ‘Venerable, you have been accused at the wrong time, not the right time; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.4_0: You have been accused falsely, not truthfully; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.5_0: You have been accused harshly, not gently; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.6_0: You have been accused unbeneficially, not beneficially; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.7_0: You have been accused with internal ill will, not with a mind of good will; there is no need for you to have regret.’”
pli-tv-kd19:5.4.8_0: A mendicant who is accused improperly should be reassured in these five ways.”
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.10_0: So that other monks will think to accuse others truthfully.”
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.1_0: “And if a monk accuses another legitimately, in how many ways should non-regret be aroused in him?”
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.2_0: “Non-regret should be aroused in him in five ways:
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.3_0: ‘Venerable, you’re accusing at the right time, not the wrong time; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.4_0: You’re accusing truthfully, not falsely; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.5_0: You’re accusing gently, not harshly; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.6_0: You’re accusing beneficially, not unbeneficially; there is no need for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.7_0: You’re accusing with a mind of good will, not with internal ill will; there is no need for you to have regret.’
pli-tv-kd19:5.5.8_0: These are the five ways non-regret should be aroused in a monk who accuses another legitimately.
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.1_0: “And if a monk has been accused legitimately, in how many ways should regret be aroused in him?”
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.2_0: “Regret should be aroused in him in five ways:
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.3_0: ‘Venerable, you have been accused at the right time, not the wrong time; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.4_0: You have been accused truthfully, not falsely; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.5_0: You have been accused gently, not harshly; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.6_0: You have been accused beneficially, not unbeneficially; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.7_0: You have been accused with a mind of good will, not with internal ill will; it’s appropriate for you to have regret.’”
pli-tv-kd19:5.6.8_0: These are the five ways regret should be aroused in a monk who is accused in these five ways.”
